title-group.article-title: American Academy of Audiology Response to Gurgel et al

body.p: On behalf of the American Academy of Audiology (AAA), I would like to express concerns regarding “A New Standardized Format for Reporting Hearing Outcomes in Clinical Trials,” published in Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery by Gurgel et al.1 While we support the concept of standardized reporting methods, a standard requires investigation for validity and reliability prior to blanket implementation. Examples in this article are hypothetical, thus untested, and lack guidance on the efficacy of statistical analyses of the proposed data sets.

The suggested “minimal reporting standards” are not appropriate for all auditory clinical trials populations. Therefore the statement in Table 1 that this standard “represents the first comprehensive minimal reporting standard for clinical trials in all forms of hearing loss” should be reconsidered. Requiring these as “minimal reporting standards” for any clinical trial published in the journals of OHNS and ON may preclude their publication of some excellent clinical trials.

The pure tone average recommended (.5, 1, 2, and 3 kHz) is not optimal for trials involving noise-induced (NIHL) or ototoxic-induced hearing loss and could be insensitive to their changes in threshold sensitivity. As a primary variable, this average would miss most NIHL changes, which occur from 2 to 4 kHz, and the averaging process will dilute changes at 3 kHz.2 Thus, even successful trials of new NIHL otoprotective pharmacologic agents or devices would show negative findings using these proposed standards.

These standards would be even less sensitive to ototoxic change to determine drug-induced ototoxicity or efficacy of a new otoprotective agent to prevent drug-induced hearing loss because most clinical ototoxins cause initial hearing loss above 10 kHz. Further, the proposed standard does not reference existing guidelines, ototoxic grading systems, or scales3-7 (eg, AAA Position Statement on Ototoxicity Monitoring).3 To detect early change or measure the effectiveness of pharmaceutical otoprotectants will require auditory threshold information above 8 kHz as its primary outcome measure.

Use of word recognition is problematic in many clinical trials that may include non-English speakers, pediatric populations, ill patients, and in situations when time constraints are necessarily imposed. Word recognition also is not optimally analyzed in 10% increments but rather according to binomial distribution.8

While we appreciate the effort toward a standardized format for reporting data, this article does not present a useful standard for other stakeholders (eg, funding agencies, regulatory agencies) to evaluate study results across all forms of hearing data. Based on the information presented, we respectfully request that the current version of the Gurgel et al1 paradigm be withdrawn as a minimal reporting standard. We also would like to request the opportunity to work with the AAO-HNS to develop guidelines that better address the needs of cross-study comparisons and ensure best practices for those who use such guidelines.
Thank you for your consideration of this request. We look forward to further discussions in this area.
